articles.headline: Vigorous Defense of Human Rights Is Urged by Pope in U.N. Address
articles.snippet: Pope Benedict XVI was greeted like a rock star in New York, where he directed his attention beyond the challenges faced by the Roman Catholic Church.
articles.abstract: Pope Benedict XVI was greeted like a rock star in New York, where he directed his attention beyond the challenges faced by the Roman Catholic Church.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pope Benedict XVI arrived in New York on Friday, turning his attention beyond the challenges faced by the Roman Catholic Church: He addressed the United Nations, stressing the importance of human rights; offered Passover greetings at an Upper East Side synagogue; and met with other Christian leaders.
articles.byline: By Ian Fisher and Warren Hoge

articles.headline: Paying for College Without the Home Equity Option
articles.snippet: The turmoil in real estate has meant that home equity — often a fallback for college funds — is difficult to tap, forcing many parents to reconsider high-priced colleges.
articles.abstract: The turmoil in real estate has meant that home equity — often a fallback for college funds — is difficult to tap, forcing many parents to reconsider high-priced colleges.
articles.lead_paragraph: The colleges have given their answers. They have sent acceptance letters to high school seniors and their parents along with notifications of how much, if any, financial aid they are offering.

articles.headline: Vatican Hints at Changes in Church Laws on Abuse
articles.snippet: A top official suggested that the Roman Catholic Church is considering changes related to the statute of limitations on child sexual abuse.
articles.abstract: A top official suggested that the Roman Catholic Church is considering changes related to the statute of limitations on child sexual abuse.
articles.lead_paragraph: After three days in which Pope Benedict XVI has persistently addressed the scandal of child sexual abuse by priests, a top Vatican official said on Friday that the church was considering changes to the canon laws that govern how it handles such cases.

articles.headline: Bear Stearns’s New Hires Become Job Seekers
articles.snippet: Some students had job offers rescinded, leaving them to confront one of the worst financial job markets in years.
articles.abstract: Some students had job offers rescinded, leaving them to confront one of the worst financial job markets in years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thousands of people are losing their jobs on Wall Street  some before their first day of work.

articles.headline: China Needs Old Boys With M.B.A.’s
articles.snippet: The shortage of managerial talent in China is huge, but so too is the desire to fill that gap.
articles.abstract: The shortage of managerial talent in China is huge, but so too is the desire to fill that gap.
articles.lead_paragraph: One evening in Beijing, I wandered into a local bookstore. I couldn’t read a thing, of course, but I had been told that Chinese urbanites are voracious readers, and that I could get a feel for that in any decent bookstore. The place was enormous; its five floors of wall-to-wall books made your typical suburban Barnes & Noble look puny by comparison. Shoppers sat on the floor, reading.

articles.headline: With Guns and Fines, Brazil Takes On Loggers
articles.snippet: A crackdown is intended to send a message that the government is serious about protecting the rain forest.
articles.abstract: A crackdown is intended to send a message that the government is serious about protecting the rain forest.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALTA FLORESTA, Brazil  A convoy of six black sport utility vehicles pulled into a lumberyard unannounced here one recent morning. Out popped about two dozen members of Brazil’s security and police forces, packing sidearms and rifles. But the weapon the foreman feared most was carried by a separate group of agents of Brazil’s national environmental agency: bright yellow tape measures.

articles.headline: Zimbabwe Arms Shipped by China Spark an Uproar
articles.snippet: Dock workers put newfound pressure on South Africa and China to reduce support for Zimbabwe’s government.
articles.abstract: Dock workers put newfound pressure on South Africa and China to reduce support for Zimbabwe’s government.
articles.lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG  A Chinese ship loaded with armaments for Zimbabwe steamed into the port of Durban this week and set off a political firefight, putting newfound pressure on South Africa  and now China  to reduce support for Zimbabwe’s government as it cracks down on its rivals after a disputed election.

articles.headline: Europe Begins Testing In-Flight Use of Cellphones
articles.snippet: While airlines in the United States have shunned the use of cellphones in flight, some European and Mideast carriers are preparing to offer the service as early as this summer.
articles.abstract: While airlines in the United States have shunned the use of cellphones in flight, some European and Mideast carriers are preparing to offer the service as early as this summer.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  François Germain, a BP executive, was one of the first passengers to put Air France’s pilot program allowing cellphone calls in flight to the test. The results last week were not quite as he hoped.

articles.headline: Benefit Managers Profit by Specialty Drug Rights
articles.snippet: A growing portion of some drug benefit managers’ revenue comes from being exclusive or semi-exclusive distributors of expensive specialty drugs.
articles.abstract: A growing portion of some drug benefit managers’ revenue comes from being exclusive or semi-exclusive distributors of expensive specialty drugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Doctors treating children with a rare and severe form of epilepsy were stunned by the news. A crucial drug, H.P. Acthar Gel, that had been selling for $1,600 a vial would now cost $23,000.

articles.headline: Airline Faults Shifting Rules About Safety
articles.snippet: The Federal Aviation Administration deserves much of the blame for canceled flights, American Airlines says.
articles.abstract: The Federal Aviation Administration deserves much of the blame for canceled flights, American Airlines says.
articles.lead_paragraph: TULSA, Okla.  When American Airlines grounded 3,000 flights last week and stranded hundreds of thousands of passengers, the company’s chief executive apologized by saying he took “personal responsibility” for the safety-compliance problems.

articles.headline: McCain, Iraq War and the Threat of ‘Al Qaeda’
articles.snippet: Critics say Senator John McCain’s descriptions of the enemy in Iraq oversimplify its hydra-headed nature.
articles.abstract: Critics say Senator John McCain’s descriptions of the enemy in Iraq oversimplify its hydra-headed nature.
articles.lead_paragraph: As he campaigns with the weight of a deeply unpopular war on his shoulders, Senator John McCain of Arizona frequently uses the shorthand “Al Qaeda” to describe the enemy in Iraq in pressing to stay the course in the war there.
articles.byline: By Michael Cooper and Larry Rohter

articles.headline: Citigroup Records a Loss and Plans 9,000 Layoffs
articles.snippet: The results contained few surprises, and investors responded to the bank’s $5.1 billion loss by pushing markets sharply higher.
articles.abstract: The results contained few surprises, and investors responded to the bank’s $5.1 billion loss by pushing markets sharply higher.
articles.lead_paragraph: Vikram S. Pandit passed his first test at Citigroup. His next one may not be so easy.

articles.headline: U.S. Military Seeks to Widen Pakistan Raids
articles.snippet: The move has been rebuffed over fears that attacking Pakistani radicals may anger the new government.
articles.abstract: The move has been rebuffed over fears that attacking Pakistani radicals may anger the new government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  American commanders in Afghanistan have in recent months urged a widening of the war that could include American attacks on indigenous Pakistani militants in the tribal areas inside Pakistan, according to United States officials.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: A Star at Toyota, a Believer at Ford
articles.snippet: James D. Farley, Ford’s chief marketing officer, says he grasps that Ford is at a crossroads.
articles.abstract: James D. Farley, Ford’s chief marketing officer, says he grasps that Ford is at a crossroads.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS

articles.headline: Clintons Sort Friends: Past and Present
articles.snippet: The decisions by some Democrats to turn away have been wrenching for the Clintons, friends say.
articles.abstract: The decisions by some Democrats to turn away have been wrenching for the Clintons, friends say.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Nancy Larson’s most difficult conversation was, by far, the one with Chelsea Clinton.

articles.headline: Pope Speaks Up for Immigrants, Touching a Nerve
articles.snippet: The pope has calibrated his immigration stance with care, but his visit has stirred the crosscurrents of the debate.
articles.abstract: The pope has calibrated his immigration stance with care, but his visit has stirred the crosscurrents of the debate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as he was flying to the United States, Pope Benedict XVI spoke of protecting immigrant families, not dividing them.
articles.byline: By Daniel J. Wakin and Julia Preston

articles.headline: Behind TV Analysts, Pentagon’s Hidden Hand
articles.snippet: The Pentagon has cultivated “military analysts” in a campaign to generate favorable news coverage of the Bush administration’s wartime performance.
articles.abstract: The Pentagon has cultivated “military analysts” in a campaign to generate favorable news coverage of the Bush administration’s wartime performance.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2005, the Bush administration confronted a fresh wave of criticism over Guantánamo Bay. The detention center had just been branded “the gulag of our times” by Amnesty International, there were new allegations of abuse from United Nations human rights experts and calls were mounting for its closure.

articles.headline: Working Life (High and Low)
articles.snippet: Jean Capobianco’s employer embraced a controversial strategy, insisting that she and other staff were independent contractors, not employees.
articles.abstract: Jean Capobianco’s employer embraced a controversial strategy, insisting that she and other staff were independent contractors, not employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Jean Capobianco was diagnosed for the second time with breast cancer, her doctors ordered a mastectomy. She first contracted the disease three years earlier and suffered through seven months of chemotherapy. After her cancer came back, her husband walked out on her. “He told me he wasn’t sexually attracted to me anymore,” she said.

articles.headline: Piling On: Borrowers Buried by Fees
articles.snippet: A handful of public-minded bankruptcy court judges are exposing the questionable practices of the mortgage servicing business.
articles.abstract: A handful of public-minded bankruptcy court judges are exposing the questionable practices of the mortgage servicing business.
articles.lead_paragraph: SLOWLY but surely, a handful of public-minded bankruptcy court judges are drawing back the curtain on the mortgage servicing business, exposing, among other questionable practices, the sundry and onerous fees that big banks and financial companies levy on troubled borrowers.

articles.headline: Iraqi Army Takes Last Basra Areas From Sadr Force
articles.snippet: Despite the apparent concession of Basra, the cleric Moktada al-Sadr threatened to declare “war until liberation” if fighting against his Mahdi Army militia continued.
articles.abstract: Despite the apparent concession of Basra, the cleric Moktada al-Sadr threatened to declare “war until liberation” if fighting against his Mahdi Army militia continued.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Iraqi soldiers took control of the last bastions of the cleric Moktada al-Sadr’s militia in Basra on Saturday, and Iran’s ambassador to Baghdad strongly endorsed the Iraqi government’s monthlong military operation against the fighters.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Alissa J. Rubin

articles.headline: After Ground Zero Prayer, Pope Ministers to 60,000 in Stadium
articles.snippet: Pope Benedict XVI closed his visit to the U.S. with a reminder to the faithful that “obedience” to the authority of the church is the foundation of their religious faith.
articles.abstract: Pope Benedict XVI closed his visit to the U.S. with a reminder to the faithful that “obedience” to the authority of the church is the foundation of their religious faith.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before a crowd of nearly 60,000 people at Yankee Stadium, Pope Benedict XVI on Sunday ended his first visit to the United States as leader of the Roman Catholic Church with a reminder to the faithful that “obedience” to the authority of the church, even in a country that prizes individual freedom, is the foundation of their religious faith.

articles.headline: Paramount Ready to End Movie Sales to Showtime
articles.snippet: Viacom’s Paramount Pictures announced it would start its own premium television channel, along with MGM and Lionsgate.
articles.abstract: Viacom’s Paramount Pictures announced it would start its own premium television channel, along with MGM and Lionsgate.
articles.lead_paragraph: The sibling rivalry that is Sumner M. Redstone’s media empire turned more fractious on Sunday, as Viacom’s Paramount Pictures movie studio said it would start its own premium television channel, ending a longstanding relationship in which it sold its movies to CBS’s Showtime.

articles.headline: In the Pit, With the Pope and Memories of a Brother
articles.snippet: Pope Benedict added his own prayers at ground zero, sprinkling holy water and meeting 24 rescue workers, survivors and relatives of 9/11 victims.
articles.abstract: Pope Benedict added his own prayers at ground zero, sprinkling holy water and meeting 24 rescue workers, survivors and relatives of 9/11 victims.
articles.lead_paragraph: They found the remains of Firefighter Jimmy Riches in the rubble of the World Trade Center on March 25, 2002. A brother, Tom Riches, then just 17, walked down into the pit, and he and his father and his other two brothers carried Jimmy out on a stretcher.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez and Ian Fisher

articles.headline: Sending in the Marines (to Recruit Women)
articles.snippet: Faced with the difficulty of recruiting during a long and unpopular war, the United States Marine Corps has started marketing itself to women in a concerted way for the first time.
articles.abstract: Faced with the difficulty of recruiting during a long and unpopular war, the United States Marine Corps has started marketing itself to women in a concerted way for the first time.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE Marines are looking for a few good women.

articles.headline: In Politics, the Gaffe Goes Viral
articles.snippet: Political gaffes have now entered a supercharged ecosystem of cable, bloggers and digitally enabled mainstream media outlets. Indeed nothing is more viral than a screw-up.
articles.abstract: Political gaffes have now entered a supercharged ecosystem of cable, bloggers and digitally enabled mainstream media outlets. Indeed nothing is more viral than a screw-up.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1990, I was covering politics in Minnesota and Paul Wellstone was down double digits in the polls in the waning weeks of the Senate race. I watched in amazement as Mr. Wellstone’s campaign staff continued to fight tooth and nail for every vote, something I wrote off to a civic reflex that I didn’t possess.

articles.headline: In Push Before Vote, Obama Sharpens Tone
articles.snippet: In commercials and appearances, Senator Barack Obama has cast his opponent in one of the most negative lights of the entire 16-month campaign.
articles.abstract: In commercials and appearances, Senator Barack Obama has cast his opponent in one of the most negative lights of the entire 16-month campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: READING, Pa.  Senator Barack Obama sharpened his tone against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Sunday as the six-week Pennsylvania primary contest raced to a close, with the rivals marshaling extensive resources in a battle for undecided voters and delegates that could determine whether the Democratic nominating fight carries on.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Katharine Q. Seelye

articles.headline: Tension Over Sports Blogging
articles.snippet: Tension over sports blogging is one of the strains between sports franchises, leagues and reporters to have emerged during the digital age.
articles.abstract: Tension over sports blogging is one of the strains between sports franchises, leagues and reporters to have emerged during the digital age.
articles.lead_paragraph: Recently in Dallas, more than an hour before game time, Mark Cuban, the owner of the Dallas Mavericks, was in the locker room grinding on the Stairmaster, surrounded by several reporters  their microphones deployed, heads tilted away to avoid flying droplets of sweat.

articles.headline: A Longer Goodbye
articles.snippet: As baby boomers have begun to reach retirement age, companies have offered shorter hours, flexible locations and lighter duties, hoping to keep older workers on board longer.
articles.abstract: As baby boomers have begun to reach retirement age, companies have offered shorter hours, flexible locations and lighter duties, hoping to keep older workers on board longer.
articles.lead_paragraph: EDWARD M. HOUGHTON, a human resources executive at Pitney Bowes, was sick of traffic jams and unpredictable hours. Bina Kozak, who matches patients to cardiologists at a Scripps Health clinic in San Diego, wanted to volunteer for nonprofit agencies. James M. Wing, a pharmacist for CVS Caremark in Cincinnati, hated Ohio’s harsh winters.

articles.headline: Human Wave Flees Violence in Zimbabwe
articles.snippet: More than 1,000 people are crossing to South Africa every day, fleeing the chaos that followed Zimbabwe’s election.
articles.abstract: More than 1,000 people are crossing to South Africa every day, fleeing the chaos that followed Zimbabwe’s election.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALONG THE SOUTH AFRICA-ZIMBABWE BORDER  Sarah Ngewerume was driven to the river by despair.

articles.headline: Selling Chat on Fox, and a Sex-Enhancing Potion on the Side
articles.snippet: By day, John C. Layfield is an investment banker and professional pontificator for Fox Business Network. By night, he peddles a love potion.
articles.abstract: By day, John C. Layfield is an investment banker and professional pontificator for Fox Business Network. By night, he peddles a love potion.
articles.lead_paragraph: By day, John C. Layfield is an investment banker and professional pontificator for Fox Business Network. By night, he peddles a love potion.

articles.headline: A Web Shift in the Way Advertisers Seek Clicks
articles.snippet: So far, the threat of a recession has not slowed the migration of ad dollars to the Internet, but the slowing economy might be changing where those dollars are being spent.
articles.abstract: So far, the threat of a recession has not slowed the migration of ad dollars to the Internet, but the slowing economy might be changing where those dollars are being spent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tyler Townsend, a digital media manager who plans online advertising for travel clients at Ypartnership, an agency in Orlando, had $150,000 to spend on behalf of a Caribbean island’s visitors bureau. And this client did not care about branding  it wanted action.

articles.headline: In Lean Times, Biotech Grains Are Less Taboo
articles.snippet: Governments, consumers and food companies are feeling pressures to relax resistance to genetically engineered crops.
articles.abstract: Governments, consumers and food companies are feeling pressures to relax resistance to genetically engineered crops.
articles.lead_paragraph: Soaring food prices and global grain shortages are bringing new pressures on governments, food companies and consumers to relax their longstanding resistance to genetically engineered crops.
